items.title: War in Libya Could Drag On, Military Analysts Say
items.description: France and Italy said that they would, like Britain, send liaison officers to Libya, in what analysts said was a sign that there would be no quick and easy end to the war.

items.title: ‘Restrepo’ Director and a Photographer Killed in Libya
items.description: Tim Hetherington, the photographer who was a director and producer of the film “Restrepo,” and Chris Hondros of the Getty photo agency came under fire on the front lines of Misurata.

items.title: Baseball Takes Over Control of Los Angeles Dodgers
items.description: Commissioner Bud Selig said he would appoint someone to oversee operations of the team because of “deep concerns.”
items.byline: By MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and RICHARD SANDOMIR

media.caption: Frank McCourt, the owner of the Los Angeles Dodgers, has burdened the once prestigious franchise with more than $400 million in debt.
Los Angeles Dodgers owner Frank McCourt spoke at a news conference in Los Angeles last week.

items.title: Audience Up, ‘Idol’ Defies TV Gravity
items.description: A slight uptick in the ratings for “American Idol” reverses a trend and makes the show look increasingly like a cultural fixture.

items.title: Taliban Fan Fears of Infiltration in Afghan Forces
items.description: Deadly strikes have raised concerns among officials about enemy insurgents in police and military units.

items.title: Bits: Some iPhones Found to Store Users’ Locations
items.description: A file was discovered on the Apple iPhone and 3G iPad that stores the device’s location data.

items.title: Museums Are Finding Room for Couturiers
items.description: Behind the move lie fierce disagreements on what is art and what is not, and whose checks are acceptable.

media.caption: Roberto Capucci at the Philadelphia Museum of Art.
media.credit: Ryan Collerd for The New York Times

media.caption: Roberto Capucci at the Philadelphia Museum of Art.
media.credit: Ryan Collerd for The New York Times

items.title: For Threats of Terrorism, Two Words Will Warn
items.description: A green-to-red system implemented in 2002 is replaced by a program that means to convey more information about threats.

media.caption: Janet Napolitano.
media.credit: Michael Appleton for The New York Times

items.title: A Bonanza for All Precious Metals
items.description: Platinum and palladium prices have risen, too, as investors seek safety from the European debt crisis, global inflation and turmoil in the Middle East and North Africa.

media.caption: Gold jewelry on display in the jewelry district in New York. The contract for May delivery of gold in New York was quoted at $1,502.50 an ounce on Wednesday.

items.title: Magazine Preview: Obama’s Young Mother Abroad
items.description: In 1967, Stanley Ann Dunham took her 6-year-old son, Barry, on an adventure, transplanting him to Indonesia. She did not know just how much it would change her life, and his.

media.caption: Barack Obama with his mother in Hawaii.
media.credit: Friends and family of Stanley Ann Dunham
